thread.title: Penalty rates 'deter weekend work': Michaelia Cash
thread.title_full: Penalty rates 'deter weekend work': Michaelia Cash | afr.com

author: Primrose Riordan
title: Penalty rates 'deter weekend work': Michaelia Cash
text:
Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull with Employment Minister Michaelia Cash. Eddie Jim Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by Primrose Riordan Employment Minister Michaelia Cash has said she expects the Turnbull government to take workplace reforms to the election to seek mandate, but has indicated she is sympathetic to penalty rate changes.
After Resources Minister Josh Frydenberg says Sunday penalty rates "need to be looked at" on Sunday , and Liberal MP Andrew Nikolic agreed , Senator Cash said penalty rates "certainly seem to deter weekend work".
She also told the ABC, that it is "sad" that unions start a campaign "based on fear and deliberate misunderstanding" as soon as penalty rates and IR changes are mentioned.
But she said the she was not anticipating any changes in the employment portfolio at the moment.
Changes recommended in the final productivity commission report into industrial relations, due in November, would be considered, and if the government decides to adopt any, they will be taken to the next election.
"We are waiting for the outcome of the Productivity Commission's final report, I will review that report calmly and methodically.
"If there is a case for good and sensible change to the Fair Work framework they will be clearly outlined by the government and taken to the next election to seek a mandate," she said.
On Tuesday, Tasmanian federal Liberal MP Andrew Nikolic also added to the calls from within government for a review of weekend penalty rates , arguing the current regime is curbing business growth.
 With new Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull to reconvene The Australian Financial Review's National Reform Summit for a meeting on Thursday Senator Cash said "everything should be on the table" at the meeting of business, unions and social services groups.
